name: Khmelnytska
inspection_info: On the 11th March 2022, Khmelnytskyi nuclear power plant was inspected by the International Atomic Agency, to ensure accordance with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Two reactors were in operation, and two under construction.
tooltip_info: On the 11th March 2022, Khmelnytskyi nuclear power plant was inspected by the International Atomic Agency, to ensure accordance with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Two reactors were in operation, and two under construction.
addition_info_source: Ukraine: Current status of nuclear power installations, published on the 12 August 2022 by the Nuclear Energy Agency (NEA) [accessed on 19/08/2022].

name: Rivne (Rouno)
inspection_info: On the 22nd July 2022, Rivne NPP was inspected by the International Atomic Agency, to ensure accordance with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. On the 7th August 2022, three out of four reactors were in operation at Rivne nuclear power plant.
tooltip_info: On the 22nd July 2022, Rivne NPP was inspected by the International Atomic Agency, to ensure accordance with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. On the 7th August 2022, three out of four reactors were in operation at Rivne nuclear power plant.

name: South Ukraine
inspection_info: South Ukraine nuclear power plant has three reactors, which were all in operation on 7th August 2022.
tooltip_info: South Ukraine nuclear power plant has three reactors, which were all in operation on 7th August 2022.

name: Zaporozhye
inspection_info: On 7th August 2022, Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant had two of its six reactors in operation.
other_events: On 4th March 2022, the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant was shelled, but the resulting fire was extinguished and had no impact on essential equipment. The plant management is now under orders from the commander of the Russian forces that took control of the site. Subsequent reports have highlighted that two of the four high voltage (750 kV) offsite power lines to the site were damaged. Another high voltage line is on standby. The nuclear operator, Energoatom reports that its staff continue to operate the facility, but under extremely stressful conditions. Additionally, the nuclear safety regulator SNRIU has indicated that it is no longer in a position to oversee nuclear safety at the site. The NEA continues to monitor the situation.
tooltip_info: On 4th March 2022, the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant was shelled, but the resulting fire was extinguished and had no impact on essential equipment. The plant management is now under orders from the commander of the Russian forces that took control of the site. Subsequent reports have highlighted that two of the four high voltage (750 kV) offsite power lines to the site were damaged. Another high voltage line is on standby. The nuclear operator, Energoatom reports that its staff continue to operate the facility, but under extremely stressful conditions. Additionally, the nuclear safety regulator SNRIU has indicated that it is no longer in a position to oversee nuclear safety at the site. The NEA continues to monitor the situation. On 7th August 2022, Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant had two of its six reactors in operation.
addition_info_source: Ukraine: Current status of nuclear power installations, published on the 12 August 2022 by the Nuclear Energy Agency (NEA) [accessed on 19/08/2022].

name: Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant
other_events: The Chernobyl Exclusion Zone was the site of fighting between Russian and Ukrainian forces during the "Battle of Chernobyl" on 24 February 2022, as part of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. On 25 February, following reports of higher radiation measurements at the Chernobyl site, Ukraine’s regulatory authority stated that they may have been caused by heavy military vehicles stirring up soil still contaminated from the 1986 accident. The readings reported by the regulator were low and remained within the operational range measured in the Exclusion Zone since it was established, and was judged by the IAEA to not pose any danger to the public. On 31 March 2022 the Russian forces that had been in control of the Chernobyl NPP since 24 February had, in writing, transferred control of the NPP to Ukrainian personnel. Ukraine informed the IAEA that during the occupation the site’s analytical laboratories for radiation monitoring had been destroyed and analytical instruments stolen, broken or otherwise disabled, but by 11 May 2022 tranmission of data from the plant to the IAEA was fully re-established.
tooltip_info: The Chernobyl Exclusion Zone was the site of fighting between Russian and Ukrainian forces during the "Battle of Chernobyl" on 24 February 2022, as part of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. On 25 February, following reports of higher radiation measurements at the Chernobyl site, Ukraine’s regulatory authority stated that they may have been caused by heavy military vehicles stirring up soil still contaminated from the 1986 accident. The readings reported by the regulator were low and remained within the operational range measured in the Exclusion Zone since it was established, and was judged by the IAEA to not pose any danger to the public. On 31 March 2022 the Russian forces that had been in control of the Chernobyl NPP since 24 February had, in writing, transferred control of the NPP to Ukrainian personnel. Ukraine informed the IAEA that during the occupation the site’s analytical laboratories for radiation monitoring had been destroyed and analytical instruments stolen, broken or otherwise disabled, but by 11 May 2022 tranmission of data from the plant to the IAEA was fully re-established.
